items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are slowly falling on the River Churn. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the next few days, especially in the Cerney Wick area. Today, 16/12/2024, and overnight are forecast to be mainly dry. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the lower River Cherwell. Flooding of roads and low-lying land remains possible today, especially in the Thrupp area. Today, 16/12/2024, and overnight are forecast to be mainly dry. We expect river levels to continue falling over the coming days but will be sensitive to further rainfall.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Windrush. The flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue, especially around Bourton-on-the-Water and near the confluence with the River Thames. Today, 16/12/2024, and overnight are forecast to be mainly dry. Water levels will remain high over the next few days and sensitive to further rainfall. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are normal on the River Evenlode but remain high on the River Glyme. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today along the River Glyme in the Woodstock area. Today, 16/12/2024, and overnight are forecast to be mainly dry. Levels on the River Glyme are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days.
We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
Ginge Brook
items.message:

We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Thame. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, especially in the Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. Today, 16/12/2024, and overnight are forecast to be mainly dry. We expect river levels to continue falling over the coming days but will be sensitive to further rainfall.
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower River Avon and its tributaries. High ground water will keep river levels high. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.
The forecast is for no significant rain in the next 24 hours.
We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high within the Hundred Foot Washes. This information is correct as of 3:30 pm on Monday 16th December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 14 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 25 centimetres of water on the road. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road at Welney. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, Tuesday 17th December 2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower Colne, Monday 16th December.
Flooding to low lying land and roads may continue to affect locations near the River Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, Poyle Channel, Staines Moor and Longford.
The forecast is dry today with rain expected this week; the levels on the Lower River Colne are expected to remain high and steady. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 10am Tuesday 17th December, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No significant rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but flowing within banks on the River Dikler. Today, 16/12/2024, and overnight are forecast to be mainly dry. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling today.
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but flowing within banks on the  River Leach. Today, 16/12/2024, and overnight are forecast to be mainly dry. River levels are expected to continue falling over the coming days.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are now starting to fall slowly on the Chertsey Bourne following heavy rainfall last week. No further flooding of low lying land and roads is expected. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to continue to fall  slowly.  We will continue to monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene due to recent heavy rainfall. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Tuesday 17th December, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No significant rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Monday 16th December, particularly around midday. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours. This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 17th December.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message: River levels remain high but are falling on the Leigh Brook river gauge near Leigh Court following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Wainlode Lane. Observed peaks: Tewkesbury Upper Pound 4.11m 11/12/24 and Mythe 4.12m 11/12/2024. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, which may cause river levels to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 6pm on Tuesday, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides with minimal rainfall forecast through Tuesday. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high due to the rainfall associated with Storm Darragh. Areas most at risk include local roads and low-lying land around Thornton Lock, Stamford Bridge, Buttercrambe and Elvington. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days and levels are expected to fall slowly over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Monday 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: This flood alert has been removed as conditions have now improved.  We are closely monitoring the situation and will reissue this alert if necessary

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 03:15 on 17/12/24, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling/rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 150 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 08:00 on 17/12/24, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides. Light rainfall is forecast tomorrow.
The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this afternoon (16/12/2024) at 14:45, and is forecast to reach between 4.98m and 5.12m. The high tide tomorrow morning (17/12/2024) at 03:15 is forecast to reach between 4.680m and 4.82m. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible for these tides.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert has been removed as conditions have now improved.  We are closely monitoring the situation and will reissue this alert if necessary

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

This morning's high tide has now passed and no flooding is expected.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert has been removed as conditions have now improved.  We are closely monitoring the situation and will reissue this alert if necessary

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. 

The forecast is for no further rainfall and we expect levels to stabilise and then recede

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No further rainfall is expected and groundwater levels are predicted to level off soon.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high, but are now slowly dropping. Increased ground water is keeping levels high in some areas.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
The forecast for the next 24 hours is for no further significant rain.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No further rainfall is expected and we expect groundwater levels to stop rising soon.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Coln and tributaries. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is still expected in the Fossebridge area. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling over the next few days. Today, 16/12/2024, and overnight are forecast to be mainly dry.
We are monitoring the situation. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area as a result of persistent rainfall. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue to rise over the coming weeks and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore  be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 17/12/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley as a result of persistent rainfall. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week. We expect levels to rise over coming weeks and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 17/12/2024 or as the situation changes.
